questions.text: Which of the following is incorrect regarding innervation of the uterus? (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Sensory level is from T10 to L1

options.label: B
options.text: Uterine contractility is mediated by innervations from level T7 - T8

options.label: C
options.text: In the 1st stage of labor, pain is due to the fibers at level of T10 - L1

options.label: D
options.text: In early labor, pain is usually because of the uterine contraction

questions.correct_answer: B. Uterine contractility is mediated by innervations from level T7 - T8
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Uterine contractility is mediated by innervations from level T7 - T8

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The incorrect statement regarding the innervation of the uterus is option B. Uterine contractility is primarily mediated by hormonal mechanisms rather than by specific spinal innervations. Hormones such as estrogen, prostaglandins, and oxytocin play a significant role in inducing uterine contractions, while progesterone helps maintain uterine relaxation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Sensory level is from T10 to L1: The sensory innervation of the uterus is indeed from spinal levels T10 to L1. These afferent fibers enter the spinal cord via the inferior hypogastric plexus and are responsible for transmitting sensory information from the uterus.
  • • Option A. Sensory level is from T10 to L1:
  • • Option C. In the 1st stage of labor, pain is due to the fibers at level of T10 - L1: During the 1st stage of labor, pain is mediated by spinal segments T10 to L1. This pain is due to the distension of the cervix and lower uterine segment, as well as the contraction of the uterus.
  • • Option C. In the 1st stage of labor, pain is due to the fibers at level of T10 - L1:
  • • Option D. In early labor, pain is usually because of the uterine contraction: In early labor, pain is usually related to uterine contractions, which stimulate nociceptors in the genital tract and can cause discomfort and pain.
  • • Option D. In early labor, pain is usually because of the uterine contraction:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Uterine contractility is not mediated by innervations from spinal level T7 - T8; instead, it is primarily influenced by hormonal mechanisms.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 500, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 500, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8 th edition

questions.text: Raise in ESR during pregnancy is due to? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Fibrinogen

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Pregnancy is characterized as a hypercoagulable state, and several changes occur in the coagulation system during pregnancy. One of the significant changes is the increase in fibrinogen levels, which leads to a rise in the erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR).
  • • Key Points:
  • • Key Points:
  • • Fibrinogen Levels: During pregnancy, fibrinogen levels increase by approximately 50%, from 200-400 mg/dL to 300-600 mg/dL. This rise in fibrinogen contributes significantly to the increased ESR. ESR: The ESR can increase up to four times during pregnancy due to the increased levels of fibrinogen and globulin. Platelet Count: There may be a slight fall in platelet count during pregnancy, commonly due to gestational thrombocytopenia, which is caused by hemodilution and increased platelet consumption. This condition usually has no adverse effect on pregnancy and is often observed in the third trimester. Coagulation Factors: There is an increase in the plasma levels of several coagulation factors, including factors 1 (fibrinogen), 2, 7, 8, 9, and 10. Factors 2, 5, and 12 remain unchanged or mildly increased, while factors 11 and 13 are slightly decreased. Clotting Time: Clotting time is generally unaffected by pregnancy. Anti-Thrombin III: Levels of anti-thrombin III decrease during pregnancy.
  • • Fibrinogen Levels: During pregnancy, fibrinogen levels increase by approximately 50%, from 200-400 mg/dL to 300-600 mg/dL. This rise in fibrinogen contributes significantly to the increased ESR.
  • • Fibrinogen Levels:
  • • ESR: The ESR can increase up to four times during pregnancy due to the increased levels of fibrinogen and globulin.
  • • ESR:
  • • Platelet Count: There may be a slight fall in platelet count during pregnancy, commonly due to gestational thrombocytopenia, which is caused by hemodilution and increased platelet consumption. This condition usually has no adverse effect on pregnancy and is often observed in the third trimester.
  • • Platelet Count:
  • • Coagulation Factors: There is an increase in the plasma levels of several coagulation factors, including factors 1 (fibrinogen), 2, 7, 8, 9, and 10. Factors 2, 5, and 12 remain unchanged or mildly increased, while factors 11 and 13 are slightly decreased.
  • • Coagulation Factors:
  • • Clotting Time: Clotting time is generally unaffected by pregnancy.
  • • Clotting Time:
  • • Anti-Thrombin III: Levels of anti-thrombin III decrease during pregnancy.
  • • Anti-Thrombin III:
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Albumin: Albumin levels typically decrease during pregnancy due to hemodilution, and they do not contribute to the rise in ESR.
  • • Option A. Albumin:
  • • Option B. Platelet: Platelet count may slightly decrease due to gestational thrombocytopenia, but this does not contribute to the rise in ESR.
  • • Option B. Platelet:
  • • Option D. Anti-thrombin antibody: This is not a relevant factor in the context of ESR increase during pregnancy.
  • • Option D. Anti-thrombin antibody:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The rise in erythrocyte sedimentation rate (ESR) during pregnancy is primarily due to the increased levels of fibrinogen.
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8 th edition Pg59
  • ➤ Ref: Dutta’s textbook of obstetrics 8 th edition Pg59

questions.text: Which of the following statements is true regarding the treatment of recurrent ovarian cancer? (INICET NOV 2022)

options.label: B
options.text: Partial platinum resistant if recurrence is within 6-12 months

questions.correct_answer: C. Platinum sensitive if recurrence > 6 months
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Platinum sensitive if recurrence > 6 months

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Platinum-refractory disease : This includes women who progress during primary chemotherapy. It has the worst prognosis, as these patients do not respond to platinum-based chemotherapy at all. Platinum-resistant disease : This includes women who relapse within 6 months of completing primary therapy. Bevacizumab has been approved for the treatment of platinum-resistant disease due to its ability to inhibit angiogenesis, which is crucial for tumor growth and metastasis. Platinum-sensitive disease : This includes women who relapse more than 6 months after completing primary therapy. These patients are considered to have a better prognosis and are treated with a platinum-based combination such as carboplatin and paclitaxel or gemcitabine.
  • • Platinum-refractory disease : This includes women who progress during primary chemotherapy. It has the worst prognosis, as these patients do not respond to platinum-based chemotherapy at all.
  • • Platinum-refractory disease
  • • Platinum-resistant disease : This includes women who relapse within 6 months of completing primary therapy. Bevacizumab has been approved for the treatment of platinum-resistant disease due to its ability to inhibit angiogenesis, which is crucial for tumor growth and metastasis.
  • • Platinum-resistant disease
  • • Platinum-sensitive disease : This includes women who relapse more than 6 months after completing primary therapy. These patients are considered to have a better prognosis and are treated with a platinum-based combination such as carboplatin and paclitaxel or gemcitabine.
  • • Platinum-sensitive disease
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option A. Platinum resistant if recurrence > 12 months : This statement is incorrect. If the recurrence occurs more than 12 months after treatment, it is considered platinum-sensitive, not resistant.
  • • Option A. Platinum resistant if recurrence > 12 months
  • • Option B. Partial platinum resistant if recurrence is within 6-12 months : This statement is not a recognized classification. The classification focuses on the 6-month mark to distinguish between resistant and sensitive.
  • • Option B. Partial platinum resistant if recurrence is within 6-12 months

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Platinum-sensitive recurrent ovarian cancer is characterized by a recurrence occurring more than 6 months after completing primary therapy.
  • ➤ Ref: Berek and Novak’s gynecology 15 th edition pg 1387
  • ➤ Ref: Berek and Novak’s gynecology 15 th edition pg 1387

questions.text: A 53-year-old postmenopausal lady is detected by endometrial hyperplasia with atypia what is the next step in management? (INICET NOV 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Hysterectomy

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Postmenopausal women with atypical hyperplasia should be offered a total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy due to the very high risk of progression to malignancy. This approach effectively removes the source of hyperplasia and eliminates the potential for malignant transformation.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Progesterone: High dose Progesterones can be used to manage endometrial hyperplasia without atypia, but this is not the recommended approach for atypical hyperplasia in postmenopausal women.
  • • Option A. Progesterone:
  • • Option C. Mirena: The LNG-IUS (Mirena) can be recommended for those who want to preserve fertility and for managing endometrial hyperplasia without atypia. However, it is not suitable for postmenopausal women with atypical hyperplasia due to the high risk of progression to malignancy.
  • • Option C. Mirena:
  • • Option D. Dilatation and curettage: This procedure may be used for diagnostic purposes but is not the definitive treatment for endometrial hyperplasia with atypia in postmenopausal women.
  • • Option D. Dilatation and curettage:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Postmenopausal women with atypical endometrial hyperplasia should undergo a total hysterectomy with bilateral salpingo-oophorectomy due to the high risk of progression to malignancy.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 329, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 329, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition

questions.text: Which of the following statements is incorrect about non-invasive prenatal testing? (NEET PG 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: It uses cell-free circulating fetal DNA in the maternal serum

options.label: B
options.text: It is used for the diagnosis of trisomy 13, 18 and 21

options.label: C
options.text: It can be performed after 10 weeks of gestation

options.label: D
options.text: It is done after the routine first trimester ultrasound assessment

questions.correct_answer: B. It is used for the diagnosis of trisomy 13, 18 and 21
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) It is used for the diagnosis of trisomy 13, 18, and 21

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) is a screening tool, not a diagnostic tool. It uses cell-free fetal DNA circulating in the maternal serum to screen for certain genetic conditions, including trisomies 13, 18, and 21.
  • • NIPT is not used for diagnosis but for screening. It has high sensitivity (about 99%) for detecting trisomies 21, 18, and 13, but positive results must be confirmed with diagnostic tests such as chorionic villus sampling (CVS) or amniocentesis.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. It uses cell-free circulating fetal DNA in the maternal serum : Correct. NIPT uses cell-free circulating fetal DNA in the maternal serum to assess the risk of certain genetic conditions in the fetus.
  • • Option A. It uses cell-free circulating fetal DNA in the maternal serum
  • • Option C. It can be performed after 10 weeks of gestation : Correct. NIPT can be performed after 10 weeks of gestation, when there is enough fetal DNA in the maternal blood for accurate analysis.
  • • Option C.
  • • It can be performed after 10 weeks of gestation
  • • Option D. It is done after the routine first trimester ultrasound assessment : Correct. NIPT is often done after the routine first trimester ultrasound assessment, which helps determine gestational age and detect multiple pregnancies or major anomalies.
  • • Option D. It is done after the routine first trimester ultrasound assessment

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Non-invasive prenatal testing (NIPT) is a screening test for aneuploidy using cell-free fetal DNA in maternal serum, typically performed after 10 weeks of gestation.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 890, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 890, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: Which of the following is a contraindication to given drug? (FMGE JAN 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Malpresentation of fetus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given drug in the image is Oxytocin, which is commonly used to induce or augment labor. However, its use is contraindicated in several conditions to avoid complications during childbirth. One such contraindication is malpresentation of the fetus, where the fetus is not in a head-down position, potentially complicating a vaginal delivery.
  • • Contraindications to Oxytocin:
  • • Contraindications to Oxytocin:
  • • Grand multipara: Women who have given birth five or more times. Contracted pelvis: A pelvis that is too small to allow the passage of the fetus. History of Classical Cesarean Section: Classical C-sections involve a vertical incision in the uterus, increasing the risk of uterine rupture. History of 2 or more Lower Segment Cesarean Sections (LSCS): Multiple C-sections also increase the risk of uterine rupture. Malpresentation: Includes breech, transverse, or any non-cephalic presentation of the fetus. Obstructed labor: Labor that does not progress due to physical obstruction. Fetal distress: Signs that the fetus is not well, such as abnormal heart rate patterns. Hypovolemia: Reduced blood volume in the mother, which can complicate the use of oxytocin.
  • • Grand multipara: Women who have given birth five or more times.
  • • Grand multipara:
  • • Contracted pelvis: A pelvis that is too small to allow the passage of the fetus.
  • • Contracted pelvis:
  • • History of Classical Cesarean Section: Classical C-sections involve a vertical incision in the uterus, increasing the risk of uterine rupture.
  • • History of Classical Cesarean Section:
  • • History of 2 or more Lower Segment Cesarean Sections (LSCS): Multiple C-sections also increase the risk of uterine rupture.
  • • History of 2 or more Lower Segment Cesarean Sections (LSCS):
  • • Malpresentation: Includes breech, transverse, or any non-cephalic presentation of the fetus.
  • • Malpresentation:
  • • Obstructed labor: Labor that does not progress due to physical obstruction.
  • • Obstructed labor:
  • • Fetal distress: Signs that the fetus is not well, such as abnormal heart rate patterns.
  • • Fetal distress:
  • • Hypovolemia: Reduced blood volume in the mother, which can complicate the use of oxytocin.
  • • Hypovolemia:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Heart disease in mother : Heart disease in the mother is considered a relative contraindication for oxytocin administration. It requires careful monitoring and assessment by the healthcare provider, but it is not an absolute contraindication.
  • • Option B. Heart disease in mother
  • • Option C. Premature labour : Oxytocin can sometimes be used to manage labor in preterm situations under strict medical supervision. It is not an absolute contraindication.
  • • Option C. Premature labour
  • • Option D. Hypothyroidism : Hypothyroidism is not a contraindication for the use of oxytocin. Proper management of hypothyroidism is necessary during pregnancy, but it does not specifically preclude the use of oxytocin.
  • • Option D. Hypothyroidism

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Oxytocin is contraindicated in malpresentation of the fetus, grand multipara, contracted pelvis, history of classical cesarean, history of 2 or more LSCS, obstructed labor, fetal distress, and hypovolemia.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 573, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 226 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 573, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 226 th edition

questions.text: After successful delivery of the baby, the obstetrician witnesses that the episiotomy performed has extended backwards beyond the perineal body. Which among the following structures is likely to be injured in this case? (NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) External anal sphincter

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Obstetrical Anal Sphincter Injuries (OASIS) include third and fourth-degree lacerations. Third-degree lacerations involve the external anal sphincter: 3A: Less than 50% of the external anal sphincter torn. 3B: More than 50% of the external anal sphincter torn. 3C: Both the external and internal anal sphincter torn. Fourth-degree lacerations extend to the rectal mucosa. In the scenario mentioned, the episiotomy has extended backward beyond the perineal body, likely damaging the anal sphincter and potentially the anal mucosa.
  • • Obstetrical Anal Sphincter Injuries (OASIS) include third and fourth-degree lacerations.
  • • Third-degree lacerations involve the external anal sphincter: 3A: Less than 50% of the external anal sphincter torn. 3B: More than 50% of the external anal sphincter torn. 3C: Both the external and internal anal sphincter torn.
  • • Third-degree lacerations
  • • 3A: Less than 50% of the external anal sphincter torn. 3B: More than 50% of the external anal sphincter torn. 3C: Both the external and internal anal sphincter torn.
  • • 3A: Less than 50% of the external anal sphincter torn.
  • • 3A:
  • • 3B: More than 50% of the external anal sphincter torn.
  • • 3B:
  • • 3C: Both the external and internal anal sphincter torn.
  • • 3C:
  • • Fourth-degree lacerations extend to the rectal mucosa.
  • • Fourth-degree lacerations
  • • In the scenario mentioned, the episiotomy has extended backward beyond the perineal body, likely damaging the anal sphincter and potentially the anal mucosa.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B: Ischiocavernosus: This muscle is located more laterally and is less likely to be involved in a backward extension of the episiotomy.
  • • Option B: Ischiocavernosus:
  • • Option C: Bulbospongiosus: This muscle is located in the perineal body and is usually affected by a standard episiotomy, but not specifically by a backward extension beyond the perineal body.
  • • Option C: Bulbospongiosus:
  • • Option D: Urethral sphincter: This sphincter is located anteriorly and is not involved in a backward extension of the episiotomy.
  • • Option D: Urethral sphincter:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases where an episiotomy extends backward beyond the perineal body, the external anal sphincter is the structure most likely to be injured.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1307, Williams Obstetrics, 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 1307, Williams Obstetrics, 26 th edition

questions.text: A pregnant woman has cramps in her legs. What will you suggest to her to relieve the pain? (INICET MAY 2020)

options.label: C
options.text: Extend knee and plantar flex foot

options.label: D
options.text: Flex knee and plantar flex foot

questions.correct_answer: A. Extend knee and dorsiflex foot
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Extend knee and dorsiflex foot

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • To relieve leg cramps, the recommended technique is to:
  • • Extend the knee : Straightening the leg helps in relieving tension and alleviating the cramp. Dorsiflex the foot : This involves pulling the toes towards the shin, which stretches the calf muscles and helps in reducing the cramp.
  • • Extend the knee : Straightening the leg helps in relieving tension and alleviating the cramp.
  • • Extend the knee
  • • Dorsiflex the foot : This involves pulling the toes towards the shin, which stretches the calf muscles and helps in reducing the cramp.
  • • Dorsiflex the foot
  • • Leg cramps during pregnancy are commonly caused by factors such as deficiencies in serum calcium, elevated serum phosphorus, or increased pressure on the leg veins. Stretching and adjusting the foot position can provide immediate relief from cramps.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Flex knee and dorsiflex foot : Flexing the knee while dorsiflexing the foot can help in some cases, but extending the knee is generally more effective in relieving cramp pain.
  • • Option B. Flex knee and dorsiflex foot
  • • Option C. Extend knee and plantar flex foot : Plantar flexion (pointing the toes downward) can actually exacerbate calf cramps. Extending the knee while performing plantar flexion is not as effective for cramp relief.
  • • Option C. Extend knee and plantar flex foot
  • • Option D. Flex knee and plantar flex foot : Flexing the knee while performing plantar flexion will likely increase the cramp discomfort. This position may not provide effective relief.
  • • Option D. Flex knee and plantar flex foot

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ To relieve leg cramps during pregnancy, extend the knee and dorsiflex the foot.
  • ➤ Ref: https://americanpregnancy.org/healthy-pregnancy/pregnancy-health-wellness/leg-cramps-during-pregnancy
  • ➤ Ref:
  • ➤ https://americanpregnancy.org/healthy-pregnancy/pregnancy-health-wellness/leg-cramps-during-pregnancy

questions.text: Which of the following statements is false about the umbilical cord? (NEET PG 2018)

options.label: A
options.text: It has one artery and two veins

options.label: B
options.text: It contains a gelatinous substance called Wharton's jelly

options.label: C
options.text: Presence of a single umbilical artery is associated with congenital anomalies

options.label: D
options.text: Normal average umbilical cord length is 50-60 cm

questions.correct_answer: A. It has one artery and two veins
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) It has one artery and two veins

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The umbilical cord has two arteries and one vein. This 3 vessel umbilical cord appears as a “mickey-mouse sign” manner on the ultrasound finding The umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus and the 2 umbilical arteries carry deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta
  • • The umbilical cord has two arteries and one vein.
  • • This 3 vessel umbilical cord appears as a “mickey-mouse sign” manner on the ultrasound finding
  • • The umbilical vein carries oxygenated blood from the placenta to the fetus and the 2 umbilical arteries carry deoxygenated blood from the fetus to the placenta
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. It contains a gelatinous substance called Wharton's jelly : Wharton’s jelly is the gelatinous material surrounding the umbilical cord which protects it from external forces
  • • Option B. It contains a gelatinous substance called Wharton's jelly
  • • Option C. Presence of a single umbilical artery is associated with congenital anomalies : A single umbilical artery is the most common anomaly in an umbilical cord.
  • • Option C. Presence of a single umbilical artery is associated with congenital anomalies
  • • It is associated with congenital anomalies such as genitourinary and cardiac anomalies
  • • It may also be associated with Trisomy 18 (Edward syndrome) and other chromosomal anomalies
  • • Option D. Normal average umbilical cord length is 50-60 cm : The average length of the umbilical cord is 50 cm
  • • Option D. Normal average umbilical cord length is 50-60 cm
  • • Educational objective :
  • • Educational objective
  • • The umbilical cord has two arteries and one vein.
  • • Ref: Page no 44, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8 th edition
  • • Ref: Page no 44, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8 th edition

questions.text: A 39-year-old G6P2L1A3 presents with a history of previous 2 LSCS with PAS. What will you NOT counsel her about? (INICET NOV 2023)

options.label: B
options.text: Risk of bladder injury in case of PAS

options.label: C
options.text: Risk of bowel injury in case of PAS

questions.text: Long-standing pelvic inflammation may lead to which of the following conditions? (NEET PG 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Pyometra

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Long-standing pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) involves infection and inflammation of the upper genital tract, which can include the uterus, fallopian tubes, and ovaries. PID can result from sexually transmitted infections and, if left untreated, can lead to several serious complications.
  • • Complications of long-standing pelvic inflammation include:
  • • Complications of long-standing pelvic inflammation include:
  • • Infertility: Due to damage to the fallopian tubes and the resulting adhesions, which can block the passage of eggs from the ovaries to the uterus. Ectopic pregnancy: Scarring of the fallopian tubes can cause a fertilized egg to implant outside the uterus, most commonly in the tubes. Pyometra: Accumulation of pus within the uterine cavity, often due to obstruction of the cervical canal combined with chronic infection. Dyspareunia: Pain during sexual intercourse, often due to adhesions and chronic pelvic pain. Chronic pelvic pain: Persistent pain in the lower abdomen, which can be severe and debilitating. Frozen pelvis: Severe adhesions can cause the pelvic organs to become fixed in place, leading to significant pain and dysfunction.
  • • Infertility: Due to damage to the fallopian tubes and the resulting adhesions, which can block the passage of eggs from the ovaries to the uterus.
  • • Infertility:
  • • Ectopic pregnancy: Scarring of the fallopian tubes can cause a fertilized egg to implant outside the uterus, most commonly in the tubes.
  • • Ectopic pregnancy:
  • • Pyometra: Accumulation of pus within the uterine cavity, often due to obstruction of the cervical canal combined with chronic infection.
  • • Pyometra:
  • • Dyspareunia: Pain during sexual intercourse, often due to adhesions and chronic pelvic pain.
  • • Dyspareunia:
  • • Chronic pelvic pain: Persistent pain in the lower abdomen, which can be severe and debilitating.
  • • Chronic pelvic pain:
  • • Frozen pelvis: Severe adhesions can cause the pelvic organs to become fixed in place, leading to significant pain and dysfunction.
  • • Frozen pelvis:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Uterine polyposis : Uterine polyposis involves the development of benign polyps within the endometrial cavity and is not typically a direct result of PID.
  • • Option B. Uterine polyposis
  • • Option C. Pseudocyesis : Pseudocyesis, or false pregnancy, is a psychological condition where a woman believes she is pregnant and may exhibit pregnancy symptoms, but is not related to PID.
  • • Option C. Pseudocyesis
  • • Option D. Endometrial hyperplasia : Endometrial hyperplasia refers to the thickening of the endometrial lining due to excess estrogen stimulation and is not a direct consequence of PID.
  • • Option D. Endometrial hyperplasia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Long-standing pelvic inflammatory disease (PID) can lead to serious complications such as infertility, ectopic pregnancy, chronic pelvic pain, and pyometra.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 155, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology 6 th edition

questions.text: A 28-year primigravida presents at 36 weeks with painful vulval ulcers. She does not give history of similar lesions ever in the past. On examination, there are multiple painful vesicular lesions. Which is the best treatment option? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.correct_answer: A. Acyclovir and elective Cesarean section
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Acyclovir and elective Cesarean section

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Acyclovir and elective Cesarean section:
  • • Acyclovir and elective Cesarean section:
  • • The diagnosis in this woman is genital herpes simplex (HSV). Since she has never had similar lesions in the past, this is primary genital herpes. The risk of neonatal infection following vaginal delivery with primary HSV is very high (up to 50%). Neonatal herpes has a very high mortality rate. Antivirals (Acyclovir) have to be started. Hence, the recommended mode of delivery in primary HSV is elective Cesarean section to prevent transmission to the neonate.
  • • The diagnosis in this woman is genital herpes simplex (HSV).
  • • Since she has never had similar lesions in the past, this is primary genital herpes.
  • • The risk of neonatal infection following vaginal delivery with primary HSV is very high (up to 50%). Neonatal herpes has a very high mortality rate.
  • • Antivirals (Acyclovir) have to be started.
  • • Hence, the recommended mode of delivery in primary HSV is elective Cesarean section to prevent transmission to the neonate.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Acyclovir and induction of labor: While acyclovir is appropriate for treating HSV, inducing labor is not recommended due to the high risk of neonatal infection with vaginal delivery in the presence of active primary HSV lesions.
  • • Option B. Acyclovir and induction of labor:
  • • Option C. Spontaneous delivery: Spontaneous vaginal delivery poses a significant risk of neonatal herpes, which can lead to severe complications and high mortality. This is not recommended in the case of primary genital HSV.
  • • Option C. Spontaneous delivery:
  • • Option D. Antiviral and normal vaginal delivery: Antiviral treatment is necessary, but normal vaginal delivery is not recommended due to the high risk of transmitting HSV to the neonate. Cesarean section is the preferred mode of delivery.
  • • Option D. Antiviral and normal vaginal delivery:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In cases of primary genital herpes simplex virus (HSV) infection at term, the best treatment option is to start antiviral therapy and plan for an elective Cesarean section to reduce the risk of neonatal herpes infection.

questions.text: Which of the following is not a cause of secondary amenorrhea? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.explanation:

  • • Causes of secondary amenorrhea:
  • • Causes of secondary amenorrhea:
  • • Sheehan's syndrome: This is a condition where the pituitary gland is damaged due to severe blood loss during or after childbirth, leading to secondary amenorrhea. Asherman's syndrome: This condition involves the formation of scar tissue in the uterine cavity, often as a result of surgical procedures like dilation and curettage (D&C), leading to secondary amenorrhea. Turner mosaic: This refers to a form of Turner syndrome where some of the cells have the typical 45,X karyotype and others have a different karyotype (e.g., 46,XX). It can lead to secondary amenorrhea. Premature ovarian failure: This condition occurs when the ovaries stop functioning normally before age 40, causing secondary amenorrhea.

questions.text: A 27y primigravida has just delivered. When removing the placenta, uterine inversion is noted. What is the next immediate step? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)

options.label: B
options.text: Remove the placenta and reposition the uterus

options.label: C
options.text: Reposition the uterus with the placenta attached

questions.correct_answer: C. Reposition the uterus with the placenta attached
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Reposition the uterus with the placenta attached

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Uterine inversion is a rare but serious obstetric emergency that occurs when the uterus turns inside out after delivery. Immediate management is crucial to prevent severe hemorrhage and shock. The next immediate step in the management of uterine inversion is to manually reposition the uterus with the placenta still attached. This is done to quickly restore the uterus to its normal position and reduce the risk of continued bleeding and shock.
  • • After manually repositioning the uterus, the healthcare provider should maintain the position by keeping a fist inside the uterus and administering uterotonic agents such as oxytocin to promote uterine contractions, which help to keep the uterus in place and reduce bleeding. The placenta should only be removed after the uterus has been repositioned successfully.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Shift to OT immediately: While surgical intervention may be required if manual repositioning fails, the initial step is to manually reposition the uterus.
  • • Option A. Shift to OT immediately:
  • • Option B. Remove the placenta and reposition the uterus: Removing the placenta before repositioning the uterus can lead to increased bleeding and is not recommended.
  • • Option B. Remove the placenta and reposition the uterus:
  • • Option D. O'Sullivan's hydrostatic maneuver: This maneuver involves using fluid pressure to reposition the uterus and is used if manual repositioning fails. It is not the immediate next step.
  • • Option D. O'Sullivan's hydrostatic maneuver:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The immediate step in managing uterine inversion is to manually reposition the uterus with the placenta still attached, followed by administration of uterotonic agents to maintain the uterus in its correct position.

questions.text: In POP Q staging, the reference point taken is? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Hymen

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The Pelvic Organ Prolapse Quantification (POP-Q) system is a standardized method for assessing and quantifying the severity of pelvic organ prolapse. The reference point in POP-Q staging is the hymen. All measurements in the POP-Q system are taken relative to the hymen, which serves as a fixed anatomical landmark.
  • • The POP-Q system involves six specific points and three measurements:
  • • Points:
  • • Points:
  • • Aa: A point on the anterior vaginal wall, 3 cm proximal to the hymen.
  • • Ba: The most distal position of any part of the anterior vaginal wall.
  • • C: The cervix or the vaginal cuff after hysterectomy.

  • • Measurements:

  • • Educational objective:

questions.text: Which statement is false regarding late decelerations? (INICET MAY 2022)

options.label: A
options.text: Starts after peak of uterine contraction and ends after uterine contraction ends

options.label: C
options.text: ﻿﻿﻿At least 10 beats, 2 times in a 20 min period above baseline

questions.correct_answer: C. ﻿﻿﻿At least 10 beats, 2 times in a 20 min period above baseline
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) At least 10 beats, 2 times in a 20 min period above baseline

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Incorrect. Late decelerations are defined by a decrease in fetal heart rate that is typically more than 15 beats per minute below the baseline and is not defined by a specific frequency above baseline. The characteristic depth and timing of the deceleration are more important than the number of beats or frequency above the baseline.
  • • Late decelerations in fetal heart rate patterns are important indicators of fetal well-being and uteroplacental function. Understanding their characteristics is crucial for accurate assessment.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Starts after peak of uterine contraction and ends after uterine contraction ends: Correct. Late decelerations start after the peak of the uterine contraction and end after the contraction has concluded. This delayed onset and resolution are key features.
  • • Option A. Starts after peak of uterine contraction and ends after uterine contraction ends:
  • • Option B. They are smooth and gradual: Correct. Late decelerations are characterized by a smooth and gradual decline in fetal heart rate (FHR).
  • • Option B. They are smooth and gradual:
  • • Option D. Not associated with accelerations: Correct. Late decelerations are not typically associated with accelerations. This differentiates them from other types of decelerations, such as early decelerations, which can be accompanied by accelerations.
  • • Option D. Not associated with accelerations:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Late decelerations are characterized by a smooth, gradual decline in fetal heart rate that begins after the peak of a uterine contraction and returns to baseline after the contraction ends, and they are not defined by beats above baseline or associated with accelerations.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 693, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 693, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics, 8 th edition

Fetal urine is the major contributor for amniotic fluid post 20 weeks.
  • • Fetal urine production begins from 8-11 weeks period of gestation
  • • In the first trimester, amniotic fluid is generally composed of extracellular fluid secreted across the amnion via trans membranous flow; across the fetal vessels on placental surface via intramembranous flow; and via transcutaneous flow across fetal skin.

  • • Option B. Fetal skin:
  • • Option C. Fetal lung fluid: Fetal lung fluid contributes to the amniotic fluid but not as significantly as fetal urine post 20 weeks.
  • • Option C. Fetal lung fluid:
  • • Option D. Maternal plasma: Maternal plasma contributes indirectly to amniotic fluid via transmembranous flow, but it is not the major contributor post 20 weeks.
  • • Option D. Maternal plasma:

questions.text: A lady who is 38 weeks pregnant comes to the OPD for a routine checkup. She has a history of normal twin delivery at term 4 years ago. What is her gravida and para score? (NEET PG 2020)

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The obstetric score is used to summarize the past obstetric history as follows: G - Gravidity, denoting the total number of pregnancies, including the present one P - Parity, denoting the total number of pregnancies crossing the period of viability This includes both live births and stillbirths The current pregnancy is not included A - Abortus or the number of pregnancies that were lost for any reason, including induced abortions or miscarriages L - Living children. The GTPAL system includes the following: Gravida Term (>37 weeks) Preterm (20w - 36w 6d) Abortions (<20 weeks) Number of living children

  • • P - Parity, denoting the total number of pregnancies crossing the period of viability
  • • This includes both live births and stillbirths

questions.text: Non-immune hydrops is seen in all, except? (INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Human immunodeficiency virus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Non-immune hydrops fetalis is a condition characterized by an abnormal accumulation of fluid in at least two fetal compartments, such as ascites, pleural effusion, pericardial effusion, or skin edema, not caused by maternal alloimmunization. Pathogenesis includes decreased colloid oncotic pressure, increased hydrostatic or central venous pressure, and enhanced vascular permeability. These factors can lead to the development of fetal effusions and anasarca (generalized edema). Infectious causes of non-immune hydrops include parvovirus B19, syphilis, cytomegalovirus, toxoplasmosis, rubella, enterovirus, varicella, herpes simplex, coxsackievirus, listeriosis, leptospirosis, Chagas disease, and Lyme disease.
  • • Non-immune hydrops fetalis is a condition characterized by an abnormal accumulation of fluid in at least two fetal compartments, such as ascites, pleural effusion, pericardial effusion, or skin edema, not caused by maternal alloimmunization.
  • • Pathogenesis includes decreased colloid oncotic pressure, increased hydrostatic or central venous pressure, and enhanced vascular permeability. These factors can lead to the development of fetal effusions and anasarca (generalized edema).
  • • Infectious causes of non-immune hydrops include parvovirus B19, syphilis, cytomegalovirus, toxoplasmosis, rubella, enterovirus, varicella, herpes simplex, coxsackievirus, listeriosis, leptospirosis, Chagas disease, and Lyme disease.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Herpes simplex virus : This virus can cause non-immune hydrops due to fetal infection leading to systemic inflammation and multiorgan failure.
  • • Option B. Herpes simplex virus
  • • Option C. Syphilis : A congenital infection with syphilis can cause severe fetal anemia and hydrops fetalis.
  • • Option C. Syphilis
  • • Option D. Parvovirus B19 : This virus is a well-known cause of non-immune hydrops due to its predilection for infecting red blood cell precursors, leading to severe fetal anemia and hydrops.
  • • Option D. Parvovirus B19

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) is not a cause of non-immune hydrops fetalis.
  • ➤ Ref: Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition page no 926
  • ➤ Ref: Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition page no 926

questions.text: An 80-year-old woman complains of leakage of urine on straining and coughing. What is the diagnosis? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Stress urinary incontinence

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Stress urinary incontinence (SUI) occurs when there is involuntary leakage of urine during activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure, such as straining, coughing, sneezing, or exercising. This condition is often due to weakness of the pelvic floor muscles and the urethral sphincter, which fail to properly support the bladder and urethra.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Urge urinary incontinence : This type of incontinence is characterized by a sudden and intense urge to urinate, followed by involuntary leakage of urine. It is commonly associated with an overactive bladder.
  • • Option B. Urge urinary incontinence
  • • Option C. Mixed urinary incontinence : This occurs when a person experiences symptoms of both stress and urge urinary incontinence.
  • • Option C. Mixed urinary incontinence
  • • Option D. Overflow incontinence : This type occurs when the bladder fails to empty completely, leading to leakage of small amounts of urine. It is often associated with bladder outlet obstruction or neurological conditions affecting bladder function.
  • • Option D. Overflow incontinence

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Stress urinary incontinence is diagnosed when an individual experiences leakage of urine during activities that increase intra-abdominal pressure, such as straining or coughing, due to weakened pelvic floor muscles and urethral sphincter.

questions.text: A woman in labour presented to the ER. A vaginal breech delivery was planned for her. What statement regarding the management is false? (INICET MAY 2020)

options.label: B

options.label: C
options.text: Continuous FHR monitoring is required for breech delivery during labor

options.label: D
options.text: Should be done by a skilled obstetrician

questions.correct_answer: A. Breech identified for the first-time during delivery is a contraindication for normal delivery
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Breech identified for the first-time during delivery is a contraindication for normal delivery

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The statement that breech presentation identified for the first time during delivery is a contraindication for normal delivery is false.
  • • Breech identified for the first-time during delivery is not automatically a contraindication for a vaginal breech delivery. It is crucial to assess the situation carefully, considering the skill of the obstetrician and the facilities available, but it does not universally rule out the possibility of a vaginal breech delivery.
  • • Breech identified for the first-time during delivery
  • • Other options:
  • • Other options:
  • • Option B. Breech delivery is done in a hospital where a facility for emergency CS is available : This is correct because the presence of a facility for emergency cesarean section is essential for managing unexpected complications during a breech delivery.
  • • Option B. Breech delivery is done in a hospital where a facility for emergency CS is available
  • • Option C. Continuous FHR monitoring is required for breech delivery during labor : This is correct because continuous fetal heart rate monitoring is crucial to detect any signs of fetal distress during a breech delivery.
  • • Option C. Continuous FHR monitoring is required for breech delivery during labor
  • • Option D. Should be done by a skilled obstetrician : This is correct as vaginal breech deliveries should be performed by an experienced and skilled obstetrician to manage the potential risks and complications effectively.
  • • Option D. Should be done by a skilled obstetrician

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Breech presentation identified for the first-time during delivery is not an automatic contraindication for vaginal delivery, provided other criteria are met and facilities are available.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 449, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Obstetrics 8 th edition.

questions.text: The results of semen analysis of a young male have been given below. What is the diagnosis? 5 million/mI concentration, 50% motility, 4% normal morphology? (INICET NOV 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Oligospermia

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The given semen analysis results show a sperm concentration of 5 million/mL, which is below the normal reference value set by the WHO. According to the WHO 2021 guidelines, a normal sperm concentration is 16 million/mL or higher. Therefore, this patient has oligospermia, which is defined as a sperm concentration of less than 15 million/mL. Counts below 5 million/mL are considered severe.
  • • Key Points:
  • • Key Points:
  • • Oligospermia: Sperm concentration <15 million/mL. Severe oligospermia is when counts are <5 million/mL. Teratozoospermia: Abnormal sperm morphology. Asthenozoospermia: No motile sperms or diminished motility. Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia: A combination of low sperm count, poor motility, and abnormal morphology.
  • • Oligospermia: Sperm concentration <15 million/mL. Severe oligospermia is when counts are <5 million/mL.
  • • Oligospermia:
  • • Teratozoospermia: Abnormal sperm morphology.
  • • Teratozoospermia:
  • • Asthenozoospermia: No motile sperms or diminished motility.
  • • Asthenozoospermia:
  • • Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia: A combination of low sperm count, poor motility, and abnormal morphology.
  • • Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Teratozoospermia: Teratozoospermia refers to abnormal sperm morphology. The morphology here is 4%, which is within the normal range according to WHO criteria.
  • • Option B. Teratozoospermia:
  • • Option C. Asthenozoospermia: Asthenozoospermia refers to reduced sperm motility. In this case, the motility is 50%, which is normal.
  • • Option C. Asthenozoospermia:
  • • Option D. Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia: This term describes a condition where there is a combination of low sperm count, poor motility, and abnormal morphology. In this case, only the sperm concentration is abnormal.
  • • Option D. Oligoasthenoteratozoospermia:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Oligospermia is defined as a sperm concentration of less than 15 million/mL, with counts below 5 million/mL considered severe. The given semen analysis results show oligospermia based on the sperm concentration of 5 million/mL.
  • ➤ Ref: William’s textbook of gynecology 3 rd edition pg 442, Duttas textbook of gynecology 6 th edition pg232

questions.text: A 16-year-old girl presents to the OPD with a history of primary amenorrhea and cyclical pain. Perineal examination reveals a bulge protruding from the vagina. Identify the cause of this presentation? (NEET PG 2020)

options.label: A
options.text: Transverse septum in the proximal vagina

questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Imperforate hymen

This classically presents as a bluish bulge distending the hymen. The bulge (hematocolpos) is felt along the entire length of the vagina on doing a PR examination Treatment: Cruciate incision and drainage of hamatocolpos is done.

  • • O/e a bulge seen protruding from the vagina is suggestive of an imperforate hymen.
  • • This classically presents as a bluish bulge distending the hymen.
  • • The bulge (hematocolpos) is felt along the entire length of the vagina on doing a PR examination
  • • Treatment: Cruciate incision and drainage of hamatocolpos is done.
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A. Transverse septum in the proximal vagina : This also will present as primary amenorrhoea with cyclical abdominal pain as the menstrual blood accumulates inside. But on examination, the bulge wont be seen at the introitus as the obstruction is higher up in a proximal or high transverse vaginal septum.
  • • Option A. Transverse septum in the proximal vagina
  • • Option B. Complete vaginal atresia : In Complete vaginal atresia, also the symptoms of primary amenorrhoea and cyclical abdominal pain will be present, but again the obstruction will be high. There will be hematometra. Local examination will reveal an absent vagina or a bling ending vagina.
  • • Option B. Complete vaginal atresia
  • • Option D. Cervical agenesis : In cervical agenesis, again there will be hematometra, I.e. the obstruction is higher up and there will not ne any bulge seen on local exam.
  • • Option D. Cervical agenesis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ Primary amenorrhea with cyclical pain and a bulge protruding from the vagina is indicative of an imperforate hymen, requiring cruciate incision and drainage of hematocolpos.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 450, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 450, DC Dutta’s Textbook of Gynecology, 6 th edition

questions.text: In which of the following infections do both partners need to be treated? (FMGE JANUARY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Trichomoniasis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Trichomoniasis is a sexually transmitted infection (STI) caused by the protozoan Trichomonas vaginalis. In cases of trichomoniasis, it is essential to treat both the infected individual and their sexual partner(s) to prevent reinfection and to control the spread of the infection.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Bacterial vaginosis (BV): Although BV is associated with an increased risk of acquiring STIs, it is not classified as an STI itself. Therefore, routine treatment of sexual partners is not recommended.
  • • Option A. Bacterial vaginosis (BV):
  • • Option B. Candidiasis : This is typically caused by an overgrowth of Candida species, commonly Candida albicans, and is not considered an STI. Treating the sexual partner is not usually necessary unless the partner has symptoms of candidiasis.
  • • Option B. Candidiasis
  • • Option D. Genital TB : This is primarily spread through hematogenous (blood) or lymphatic routes rather than sexual transmission. Partners are not treated unless they are also diagnosed with genital tuberculosis.
  • • Option D. Genital TB

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For trichomoniasis, both partners need to be treated to prevent reinfection and control the spread of the disease.

questions.text: A 30-year-old married woman came for an infertility evaluation. On performing further investigations, intramural fibroids of sizes 7x5cm and 5x3cm were seen at the right and left cornual ends of the uterus. Her husband's semen analysis was found to be normal. What is the appropriate management of this case? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Laparoscopic Myomectomy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Laparoscopic myomectomy is indicated for intramural fibroids larger than 5 cm in women with infertility, as it can improve fertility and pregnancy outcomes.
  • ➤ Ref: Page no 232, DC Dutta’s textbook of gynecology, 8 th edition
